---
title: 'Digital coping: How frontline workers cope with digital service encounters'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-UVEZZ6PX" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Breit, E., Egeland, C., Løberg, I. B., &#38; Røhnebæk, M. T. (2021). <div id="csl-bib-meta-UVEZZ6PX" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-UVEZZ6PX" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Breit et al. conducted a study on how frontline workers manage their tasks when interacting with clients through digital platforms in employment assistance services. They found that digital tools change the work environment in two main ways. First, workers are more available to clients, which they handle by shifting some responsibilities to clients via digital platforms and reducing unnecessary inquiries. Second, the transparency of interactions increases, prompting workers to be more cautious about what they communicate to clients. These findings are important because they show how digitalization affects job roles and interactions, helping us understand the challenges and strategies in modern public service work. This study contributes valuable insights for future research and theory development in digital public service encounters.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-UVEZZ6PX" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Digital Service Encounters, Frontline Workers, Employment Assistance Services, Digitalisation, Coping Responses
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-UVEZZ6PX" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This article addresses how frontline workers cope when dealing with digitally mediated service encounters. It draws on a qualitative study of frontline workers' experiences in an increasingly digitalised work environment in the context of employment assistance services. The material shows that digitalising service encounters leads to two overall types of change for frontline employees, and the article explores related coping responses. First, the technology leads to an increased availability of the frontline workers to the clients. This is coped with by handing over, or ‘outsourcing’, responsibilities to clients through digital platforms, and by reducing what is experienced as ‘noise’ related to incoming enquiries. Second, the technology leads to increased transparency of the service interactions, which is coped with by being careful about the content of client communications. The analysis of these changes and their related coping responses contributes to the research on digital public service encounters and highlights avenues for empirical studies and theoretical development within a topical, yet little studied, field.
  </article>
